thread.title: UNindian: Brett Lee on a sticky romantic wicket
thread.title_full: UNindian: Brett Lee on a sticky romantic wicket

author: Philippa Hawker
title: UNindian: Brett Lee on a sticky romantic wicket
text:
Tannishtha Chatterjee (Meera) and Brett Lee (Will) in UnIndian. 
﻿ Full movies coverage 
Movie screening times 
​FILM
UNINDIAN​ ★★☆
(M) Selected cinemas (106 minutes)
 
UNindian is an Australian–Indian production, set in Sydney, that stars former cricketer Brett Lee in his acting debut, in a romantic comedy that has little to do with bat or ball. 
Advertisement Lee's character, Will, is an amiable teacher who runs "Aussie English" classes. He is smitten from afar with Meera​ (Tannishtha Chatterjee), a divorced single parent whose mother (Supriya Pathak) is desperate for her to find a suitable Indian husband, preferably a doctor. Meera​ values her independence and tries to dodge her mother's machinations. For reasons that gradually emerge — not just her mother's disapproval — she also prefers to keep Will at a distance. 
Undeterred, he prevails on his childhood friend TK (Arka Das) to give him a vastly simplified crash course in all things Indian and embarks enthusiastically on the task of winning her over. 
As a performer, Lee moves between the bashful and the enthusiastic, which mostly works well enough for the character. His co-star, Chatterjee, who was the lead in Sarah Gavron's Brick Lane (2007), is a relaxed, appealing presence.   
Director Anupam​ Sharma  presides over a film bristling with supporting characters and plotlines​ of varying success: a melodramatic subplot involving Meera's​ former husband feels way out of place and references to sponsors are decidedly unsubtle.
It's a film designed for broad-brush entertainment that tries to touch on some deeper issues: job discrimination, the problems that arise when people feel caught between two cultures, the notion of what it is to be Indian or "un-Indian". What it is to be Australian is more nebulous in this context: Will's Aussie English classes have a definitely retro feel, touching as they do on things like how to say "g'day" and the meaning of the term "sheila".
